elements.title: Hall of Fame for Great Americans (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that since 1976 there have been no additions to, but two removals from, the Hall of Fame for Great Americans (pictured)?

elements.title: Luis Gallego (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Luis Gallego had only completed middle-school education when he was elected to the Bolivian Chamber of Deputies?

elements.title: Tornado Cash (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Tornado Cash, a cryptocurrency tumbler, was blacklisted by the United States Department of the Treasury?

elements.title: Hans Redl (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that despite losing his left arm in World War II, Austrian tennis player Hans Redl reached the fourth round at Wimbledon in 1947?

elements.title: In Win Development (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that In Win Development designed a computer case that can be opened with a smartphone app?

elements.title: sari-inspired dresses (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Jacqueline Kennedy bought several saris during her 1962 tour of India and Pakistan to be turned into sari-inspired dresses?

elements.title: drink dust from the tombs of martyrs (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Assyrian Christian couples drink dust from the tombs of martyrs and are crowned during their weddings?

elements.title: Legends (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that an early version of the turn-based game Legends could take three to ten years to complete?
